subNodes.conversationText: [To Vroman.] Once again, young sir, I am sorry for your loss. Now, what can I do for you, ?
Can you tell me more about the Sunite paladin?
Ianth Lavillus arrived in Drawn Swords nigh one year ago.  It's said that the Flame Stone brought her here--it brings many Sunites to the area--but unlike the rest of them, she hasn't left.

It's a standing stone not far from Drawn Swords, on the edge of Northdark Wood.  It's a holy site for those who worship the goddess of love.  It is said that when those who love deeply approach the stone, it leaps into flame.
So Ianth acts as the town's protector?
Well, not in any official capacity.  Hamfast and I are glad to have her around, but the rest of the townsfolk don't like her high-handed manner.  She's from Tethyrian nobility, you know.
I'd like to ask you something else.
What is the latest news in these parts?
What isn't news, is a better question. In a place like this, you take what you can get, whether it be harvest reports from the lowlands or how fast the river's flowing.

But I take it that sort of thing doesn't interest you. [In a lower voice.] Trouble is always brewing in the Realms, you know. But it seems that this time trouble is brewing a little too close to home for my comfort.

I hear that the orcs of the Sunset Mountains are on the move--always a bad sign. But it's not because they're rallying for some new bloody but ultimately foolish cause. They're moving out of the mountains in droves--as if in flight.
Wouldn't we all like to know?  Now, do you want more gossip, or are you thirsty?
Is this conjecture or do you actually know something, old man?
Let's say I'm halfway between knowing and guessing.  There are worse places to be.
Tell me a bit about the folk of Drawn Swords.
Well, for one thing you can see a good portion of them just by looking around this room.  We're a small settlement, and the folk here are mostly hardy hunters and their families.
Who are those three men in dark blue cloaks over there?
Oh, those idlers call themselves "Saern's Sharp Swords."  They used to do fairly good work as volunteer guardsmen for Drawn Swords, but nowadays they sit around and swap tales.
Where did they get the name?
Saern was a great warrior and hunter--Hamfast's great-uncle, in fact.  He defended the town against many enemies, including hobgoblins.  He lost his life to them about forty years ago.
He organized a small force of townsfolk, and the name lives on in those braggarts; his legacy proper lives on in Hamfast.

He is a good, patient man and the leader of Drawn Swords--though I would be pretending modesty if I didn't claim to help out with some matters.  He will not be unhappy when he gets too old to lead, unless he happens to lose his skill at the forge at the same time.
Ah, there's not much to say.
<color=blue>[Diplomacy] Nonsense.  The fact that you have kept such a fine inn running in this out-of-the-way place says much by itself, and I'd like to hear more.</color>

I am of Berdusk originally, though I have traveled much.  I have traversed a good portion of ground between Athkatla and Silverymoon.  Drawn Swords is my home now, though.  Even if I wanted to leave, I'm sure Hamfast wouldn't let me!
<color=blue>[Diplomacy] Surely you jest, my good innkeep.  You must have many tales to tell.</color>

I am of Berdusk originally, though I have traveled much.  I have traversed a good portion of ground between Athkatla and Silverymoon.  Drawn Swords is my home now, though.  Even if I wanted to leave, I'm sure Hamfast wouldn't let me.

Oh, very well!  I am the son of a brewer and his poor wife.  I grew up in Berdusk, and first fell in love with Drawn Swords when I used to deliver beer here for my father.  Hamfast sold me this place for a song.
Can I see what you have to drink?
Very well.  That will be five gold pieces.
Here you are.  Wake me in four hours.
Here you are.  Wake me in eight hours.
Here you are.  Wake me at dusk.
Here you are.  Wake me in the morning.
I don't need anything at the moment, Danmar.  Farewell.
Welcome back. [Raising his eyebrow.] And a hearty welcome to you, too, Miss Lavillus.
Just so you know, Miss Lavillus, we still don't have any of the Vilhon Scarlet in stock--only the Cherry-Red.
Do you expect me to throw a fit, Danmar?  A nice glass of Vilhon Scarlet would go down well, but I do not need it to survive.
Of course, Miss Lavillus, of course.  I was only saying.  Now, what can I get you?
Can you direct me to your guests Dunne and Obern?  I need to speak with them.

The Ilmatari acolytes? Of course. They have beds in the bunk rooms upstairs. Why do you need to speak with them? I can't give out keys just to appease people's curiosity--not without them appeasing mine, you know.
<color=blue>[Diplomacy]  I come on behalf of Brother Anselm, on urgent church business.</color>
Well then, here's the key. It'll get you upstairs and into the bunk rooms. Farewell!
Oh, come now. I can't let you traipse about the inn just because you claim urgent business.

<color=yellow>[Bluff] Vroman has been terribly upset since the loss of his brother--as you can imagine--and Brother Anselm, who is very busy, told me to bring him to his acolytes for spiritual comfort.
Aye, I understand that, I do.  I apologize for prying so much.
Well then, here's the key. It'll get you upstairs and into the bunk rooms. Farewell!

"Very busy," you say?  Brother Anselm is a good sort, and I certainly appreciate his presence here in Drawn Swords and whatnot, but I've never heard of standing around in a chapel all day being called "busy"--and certainly not "very busy!"
[Intimidate] Listen, Danmar. I need to speak with them. That should be reason enough.
Well then, here's the key. It'll get you upstairs and into the bunk rooms. Farewell!
Come now. Do I look like a fool? I'll need a reason to give you this key.

[Danmar looks very grave for a moment.] Tsk! Undead in Swordskeep's own basement--And the two acolytes our chief suspects! Well, this is big news, but the secret is safe with me. [More cheerfully.] Until it's common knowledge, that is.
Well then, here's the key. It'll get you upstairs and into the bunk rooms. Farewell!
Ah, Master Thistlefall!  I see you have found an adventuring party.  I am sure it is a relief for you to get out of your Uncle Asterchord's shop and do some exploring.
Yes, Danmar.  The Backlands are full of delicate and interesting forms of life this time of year.  And, of course, <FirstName> is fine company.
Subtle and not-so-subtle forms of life, I'd imagine. Be careful! Anyhow, what can I do for the lot of you to?
Welcome back, my friend.  What can I do for you?
Can you tell me more about the Sunite paladin?
Ianth Lavillus arrived in Drawn Swords nigh one year ago.  It's said that the Flame Stone brought her here--it brings many Sunites to the area--but unlike the rest of them, she hasn't left.

It's a standing stone not far from Drawn Swords, on the edge of Northdark Wood.  It's a holy site for those who worship the goddess of love.  It is said that when those who love deeply approach the stone, it leaps into flame.
So Ianth acts as the town's protector?
Well, not in any official capacity.  Hamfast and I are glad to have her around, but the rest of the townsfolk don't like her high-handed manner.  She's from Tethyrian nobility, you know.
I'd like to ask you something else.
What is the latest news in these parts?
What isn't news, is a better question. In a place like this, you take what you can get, whether it be harvest reports from the lowlands or how fast the river's flowing.

But I take it that sort of thing doesn't interest you. [In a lower voice.] Trouble is always brewing in the Realms, you know. But it seems that this time trouble is brewing a little too close to home for my comfort.
